articles.headline: Fear of Crime Looms Large for Voters, to Republicans’ Advantage
articles.snippet: Republican candidates are focusing on crime and public safety, but their message is rooted not so much in data or policy as in voters’ feelings of unease.
articles.abstract: Republican candidates are focusing on crime and public safety, but their message is rooted not so much in data or policy as in voters’ feelings of unease.
articles.lead_paragraph: Debra Kowalski, a 49-year-old nurse in Bucks County, Pa., has been pleading with her elderly parents to move out of Philadelphia, especially after a delivery driver was shot and killed last month a few blocks from their home.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Jack Healy and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Elon Musk Begins Layoffs at Twitter
articles.snippet: The social media company’s 7,500 employees have been bracing for job cuts since Mr. Musk took it over last week.
articles.abstract: The social media company’s 7,500 employees have been bracing for job cuts since Mr. Musk took it over last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Elon Musk began laying off Twitter employees on Friday, culling the social media service’s 7,500-person work force a little over a week after completing his blockbuster buyout.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Ryan Mac

articles.headline: Worries Grow That TikTok Is New Home for Manipulated Video and Photos
articles.snippet: Misleading edits, fake news stories and deepfake images of politicians are starting to warp reality on the popular video platform.
articles.abstract: Misleading edits, fake news stories and deepfake images of politicians are starting to warp reality on the popular video platform.
articles.lead_paragraph: The alligators of TikTok are not what they seem.

articles.headline: Between Kanye and the Midterms, the Unsettling Stream of Antisemitism
articles.snippet: For American Jews, this fall has become increasingly worrisome. On Thursday alone, the F.B.I. warned of threats to New Jersey synagogues and the Nets suspended Kyrie Irving.
articles.abstract: For American Jews, this fall has become increasingly worrisome. On Thursday alone, the F.B.I. warned of threats to New Jersey synagogues and the Nets suspended Kyrie Irving.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Michael Paulson and Ruth Graham

articles.headline: Workers Expect Fast Inflation Next Year. Could That Make It a Reality?
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve chair is eyeing near-term inflation expectations, which might shape wages — and help keep prices rising rapidly.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve chair is eyeing near-term inflation expectations, which might shape wages — and help keep prices rising rapidly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amitis Oskoui, a consultant who works mostly with nonprofits and philanthropies, has not had a wage increase since inflation began to noticeably eat away at her paycheck early this year. What she has had are job offers.

articles.headline: Wisconsin Republicans Stand on the Verge of Total, Veto-Proof Power
articles.snippet: In a 50-50 battleground state, Republicans are close to capturing supermajorities in the State Legislature that would render the Democratic governor irrelevant even if he wins re-election.
articles.abstract: In a 50-50 battleground state, Republicans are close to capturing supermajorities in the State Legislature that would render the Democratic governor irrelevant even if he wins re-election.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKS FIELD, Wis. — The three counties in Wisconsin’s far northwest corner make up one of the last patches of rural America that have remained loyal to Democrats through the Obama and Trump years.

articles.headline: In Bid to Show It Is Open, Hong Kong Bends Covid Rules … for Some
articles.snippet: Three splashy events this week were meant to prove that the former British colony was still “Asia’s World City.” But Covid exemptions were provided for visitors from overseas, especially the wealthy ones.
articles.abstract: Three splashy events this week were meant to prove that the former British colony was still “Asia’s World City.” But Covid exemptions were provided for visitors from overseas, especially the wealthy ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hong Kong is eager to show the world that the city is open for business after years of pandemic restrictions. Officials this week even found themselves willing to bend some rules for visitors — as long as they could afford it.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Tiffany May

articles.headline: U.S. Added 261,000 Jobs in October, Signaling Economic Resilience
articles.snippet: Job growth is slowing but remains stronger than comfortable for the Federal Reserve, which is trying to tame high inflation.
articles.abstract: Job growth is slowing but remains stronger than comfortable for the Federal Reserve, which is trying to tame high inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: With less than a week until Election Day, a new economic report showed the strength of the job market despite policymakers’ efforts to constrain it in their fight against inflation.

articles.headline: On Social Media, Hunting for Voter Fraud Becomes a Game
articles.snippet: Players who post about irregularities are awarded points or titles, leading participants to question the legitimacy of elections.
articles.abstract: Players who post about irregularities are awarded points or titles, leading participants to question the legitimacy of elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the messaging app Telegram this week, 300 people gathered in a channel devoted to Arizona politics to play an online game.

articles.headline: Suburban Women, No Longer ‘Soccer Moms,’ Hold Key to Midterms
articles.snippet: A caricature of the suburban female voter looms large in American politics. But in battleground regions, many voters don’t fit the stereotype — and perhaps, never did.
articles.abstract: A caricature of the suburban female voter looms large in American politics. But in battleground regions, many voters don’t fit the stereotype — and perhaps, never did.
articles.lead_paragraph: The “soccer mom” was born a cliché.
articles.byline: By Dana Goldstein, Robert Gebeloff, Allison McCann and Brent McDonald
